The overlap surface is estimated using a spherical representation of the Earth. The result will vary depending on the data quality, current filters and current resolution.
The current resolution depends on the zoom level and latitude. It represents the average area covered by one pixel.

If you are not yet registered, a successful authentication will create a new account, and unlock new features. If you are already registered, a successful authentication will additionally give you access to all projects where you are already a member. User registration with MapX implies consent to collect and publish performance data of non-personally identifiable information at an aggregate level.

Here is a list of good practices to provide a seamless experience for readers:

  1. Keep it simple.
  2. It is better to create short story maps to keep the interest of your audience.
  3. For good readability, it is recommended not to exceed two slides per steps and more than two layers on the map in the same step.
  4. Pictures, videos and infographics can be useful and impactful mediums to contextualize your story. However, they should not overshadow the spatial component of your story. Maps should be at its center.
  5. Effects, transitions or 3d transformations can affect the readability of your story map on slow devices, use them sparingly.
Use cached results – if any – instead of recalculate
Warning, this could alter the geometry. For (multi) polygons, the automatic correction use a buffer of 0 around each feature. For other types, ST_MakeValid is used.

Does the data provider have the capacity to document the data and provide basic metadata (e.g. name, coordinate system, year, update frequency, description, and methodology)?
Does the data provider have the relevant mandate?
Does the data provider have a mandate or legal requirement to collect the data?
Is the data subject to internal quality control?
Has the data been subject to data quality assurance and control processes?
Is the data subject to external quality control?
Are the data sets subject to external auditing or peer review processes?
Data is machine-readable if it is in a format that can be easily structured and exploited by a computer. Good examples of machine-readable files are SQL, JSON, XML, DBF and to a lesser extent Excel
This question addresses whether the data is available online from an official source. This does not mean that the data is necessarily updated or maintained
Is the data available in a non-fragmented state?

Data is available in bulk if the whole dataset can be downloaded or accessed easily. Conversely it is considered non-bulk if the citizens are limited to just parts of the dataset (e.g., if restricted to querying a web form and retrieving a few results at a time)
Does the data comply with OGC standards?
Is the data compliant with applicable Open Geospatial Consortium standards, e.g. Web Map Service (WMS)?
‘Publicly available’ means that the data can be accessed by the public in some form either from websites or physical documents (even if the data is available for purchase)
Is the data accessible to the public without discrimination of users?
Can any user anonymously download the data or is registration required?
Is the data available free of charge?

Compliance with GEOSS data sharing principle #2: "where international instruments, national policies or legislation preclude the sharing of data as Open Data, data should be made available with minimal restrictions on use and at no more than the cost of reproduction and distribution;"
Is there an open license for the data?

This question addresses whether the dataset is openly licensed. It needs to state the terms of use or license that allow anyone to freely use, reuse or redistribute the data (subject to attribution and share alike requirements)
Does the data provider have the technical capacity to manage and update the layer?
The data provider is able to maintain, update and publish it on a regular basis
Does the data provider have a long-term mandate and financial means?
Does the data provider have a long-term mandate and related resources to ensure continuity in data collection and publication?
Can the data layer be dynamically streamed and shared using an API
Is the data interoperable with MapX to enable dynamic streaming/automatic updates?
Does the data support measuring of SDGs?
Can the dataset be aligned with measuring progress towards achievement of Sustainable Development Goals?

Use the 'static' mode if you want to share a view using a lightweight and faster version of MapX, with limited functionalities. Using this method, anyone with the shared link will be allowed to read the selected view, without the need of being registered in MapX. If you add a story map, it will start automatically, discarding any other views.

Views to display. In mode 'static', those views will be rendered automatically. Story maps will start directly. Otherwise, the views will be displayed in the list and if the selection is empty, all views of the project will be listed.
In 'static' mode, this will set the map extent to fit views layers extent, if available.
Add views to be automatically activated when the application is launched. This will enable the button 'filter activate view' and hide non-activated view.
Selection mode (if more that one collection)
Add groups of views by using collections
Setting the position of the map will show a defined spatial extend instead of exposing a representation of the whole world.
Embed the link in an <iframe> HTML tag to easily add MapX to your website.
